Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Virtual 4-D Field Education in Google Earth
Award.AbstractNarration: This project is leveraging the capabilities of the Google Earth Application Program Interface to create new learning experiences for formal and informal geoscience students of all ages. A network of geoscience instructors is creating GigaPan outcrops and virtual specimens and linking them to source locations on the Google Earth terrain. Virtual field trips with embedded outcrops and specimens are accessible via the project server and web site. Tasks are assigned to groups of students who are then free to explore the terrain in a virtual field vehicle or individually on foot. Students are thus acting as free-agent learners and participating in social networks in order to explore the terrain. They interact and collaborate with each other through texting on tasks that address geoscience learning goals outlined in national standards and college syllabi. Assessment instruments are embedded in the virtual field trips via computer logging. Automated feedback is provided to students when they wander off course or spend too much time on task. Logs are stored on the project's terabyte server for analysis of latitude-longitude-time tracks and comparison of novice versus expert approaches to tasks. Through the use of ground overlays of paleogeography, students are able to experience the Google Earth terrain during any geological period and they can follow the evolution of systems and changes of specimens in deep geologic time. These technologies allow students to go beyond the limitations of real field trips and compare the lithosphere of the Earth with that of the Moon and Mars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project focused on developing digital visualizations and educational modules to enhance and augment field-oriented geoscience education. Visualizations were developed using Google Earth: as a standalone application, as a web-browser plugin, and on mobile devices. Educational modules were developed for audiences that ranged from upper-level geoscience undergraduate students, K-12 students, and the general public. A key component of the development was testing these visualizations in classroom environments and using this feedback to iteratively re-engineer and improve the end-user products. Once these modules were considered close to completion, they were made available to the general community via two websites: www.digitalplanet.org and the PIs website: http://csmres.jmu.edu/Geollab/Whitmeyer/web/Index.htm

 

Primary products produced by this research include several educational exercises / labs for introductory and advanced geoscience courses, available at http://csmres.jmu.edu/Geollab/Whitmeyer/web/visuals/exercises.html. We have also produced a suite of web-based tools to help others with designing their own Google Earth-based visualizations and components, available at: http://csmres.jmu.edu/Geollab/Whitmeyer/web/visuals/maptools.html. We continue to work on a prototype geological information system using Google Earth for mobile devices (iPads and Android tablets) as well as standard computers. This prototype currently focuses on Virginia and the greater Shenandoah Valley region, but we continually update it to enlarge the region of coverage. It can be accessed at: http://csmres.jmu.edu/Geollab/Whitmeyer/web/visuals/GoogleEarth/VirginiaGeologicMaps.kml (for mobile devices and the standalone Google Earth application), or http://csmres.jmu.edu/Geollab/Whitmeyer/web/visuals/GoogleEarth/Virginia/VirginiaMaps.html (for use with a web browser plugin). Our most recent developments have focused on developing Google Earth based tectonic reconstructions of the geologic development of North America. Preliminary versions of these visualizations will be presented at the Geological Society of America conference in Charlotte, NC in November, 2012. Shortly after this we should have these modules available to the general public on our websites.

 

Though the NSF award that primarily funded this project (1034660) has ended, development of these modules and ideas continues. Thus, one should expect that the educational modules and resources available on the websites highlighted in the paragraphs above will continue to evolve and (hopefully) improve. User feedback is desired and encouraged; please feel free to contact the PI via email at whitmesj@jmu.edu. Note that several publications and conference presentations have resulted from this research; they are freely available on the PIs website or by emailing the PI.
